research.title: Fear and Loathing on the Campaign Trail '76 - Rolling Stone
research.summary: This article does not contain information about Hunter S. Thompson wearing a dog hair hat or smelling like a wet dog.  The text describes the author's experiences covering the 1976 presidential campaign, filled with eccentric characters, bizarre news events (like a man throwing bowling balls into the ocean), and a seemingly escalating sense of societal unease.  The passage also mentions a story about a dog mutilator in Coconut Grove, Florida.
highlights: I yelled at him, but by the time I got hold of my shotgun and ran out on the porch, he was gone. It all happened so fast that I didn’t even get the license number off the truck. '”   The voice on the radio paused for a long moment, then dipped a few octaves and went on with the story: “Several hours later, police said, Willie and two other dogs – both mongrels – were found in a vacant lot near the Dinner Key yacht marina. All three had been expertly castrated….…”

research.title: book excerpt - William McKeen
research.summary: This excerpt from *Outlaw Journalist* does not contain the anecdote about Hunter S. Thompson coming indoors smelling like a wet dog after wearing a dog hair hat.  The excerpt focuses on Thompson's assignment to cover the 1972 presidential campaign for *Rolling Stone* after the success of "Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas," his move to Washington D.C., and his family life during that period.
highlights: They resented him from the start: Slogging to the bus, pre-dawn, to witness the candidate-of-the-day shaking hands at factory shift-change, waiting in the parking lot. Cold, impatient, inhaling bus fumes, anxious about deadline, wondering what-in-the-hell is the holdup. Finally, that noisy thug in the flop hat and the athletic shoes comes down the aisle, bumping the other reports with his baggage and his trailing six pack. In the back seat, still noisy and unrepentant. You mean, we were waiting for that?

nodes.text: Hunter Thompson is an American journalist and author, famously known for his book 'Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas.'
nodes.label: Hunter Thompson
nodes.reason: The claim is fully validated by multiple independent sources, including Wikipedia, which confirm that Hunter S. Thompson is indeed an American journalist and is famously known for his book 'Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas.'

research.title: Hunter S. Thompson - Wikipedia
research.summary: Hunter S. Thompson (1937-2005) was an American journalist and author known for his gonzo journalism style.  His most famous work is *Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas* (1971), but he also wrote *Hell's Angels* (1967) after immersing himself in the Hells Angels motorcycle club, and other notable works including *Fear and Loathing on the Campaign Trail '72* (1973) and *The Rum Diary* (1998).  He's considered a countercultural figure, pioneering a subjective, immersive style of journalism.
highlights: He falls in love and gets in even more trouble than he was in the sex theater in San Francisco. "  The novel was slated to be released by Random House in 1999, and was even assigned ISBN 0-679-40694-8 , but was never published.  Thompson continued to publish irregularly in Rolling Stone , ultimately contributing 17 pieces to the magazine between 1984 and 2004. "Fear and Loathing in Elko," published in 1992, was a well-received fictional rallying cry against the nomination of Clarence Thomas to a seat on the Supreme Court of the United States . "Trapped in Mr. Bill's Neighborhood" was a largely factual account of an interview with Bill Clinton at a Little Rock, Arkansas , steakhouse.

research.title: Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas - Wikipedia
research.summary: Hunter S. Thompson's *Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas* (1971), a seminal work of gonzo journalism, details a drug-fueled trip to Las Vegas with his attorney, Dr. Gonzo.  This autobiographical novel, illustrated by Ralph Steadman,  became a two-part series in *Rolling Stone* before its book release and was later adapted into a 1998 film starring Johnny Depp and Benicio del Toro.  The book is known for its lurid descriptions of drug use and its commentary on the failures of the 1960s counterculture.
highlights: Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas is Thompson's most famous work and is known as Fear and Loathing for short; however, he later used the phrase "Fear and Loathing" in the titles of other books, essays, and magazine articles.  In a Rolling Stone magazine interview, Thompson said of the phrase: "It came out of my own sense of fear, and [is] a perfect description of that situation to me, however, I have been accused of stealing it from Nietzsche or Kafka or something. It seemed like a natural thing. "    He first used the phrase in a letter to a friend written after the Kennedy assassination , describing how he felt about whoever had shot President John F. Kennedy .

research.title: Hunter S. Thompson (Author of Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas)
research.summary: The provided text confirms that Hunter S. Thompson (1937-2005) was an American journalist and author known for *Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas*.  The Goodreads page shows he has 10,491 followers.
highlights: He is credited as the creator of Gonzo journalism, a style of reporting where reporters involve themselves in the action to such a degree that they become the central figures of their stories. He is also known for his promotion and use of psychedelics and other mind-altering substances (and to a lesser extent, alcohol and firearms), his libertarian views, and his iconoclastic contempt for authority. He committed suicide in 2005.   1 of 5 stars 2 of 5 stars 3 of 5 stars 4 of 5 stars 5 of 5 stars   1 of 5 stars 2 of 5 stars 3 of 5 stars 4 of 5 stars 5 of 5 stars

nodes.text: A hat made from dog hair, which is an unusual and specific item that can provoke a unique smell.
nodes.label: Dog Hair Hat
nodes.reason: While there is evidence supporting that dog hair can be spun into yarn and made into items like hats, there is limited independent research specifically addressing the claim about the unique smell of such hats, leaving some uncertainty about the olfactory effects.

research.title: Preparing and Spinning Dog Hair - Spinning Chiengora
research.summary: Spinning dog hair (chiengora) into yarn is possible, and has historical precedent.  The best breeds for this have long, double coats that shed readily, providing the soft undercoat needed for spinning.  While some find the idea repulsive, others see it as a unique way to memorialize a pet. The author details their experience and recommends the Ravelry forum "Spinning Dog Fiber - aka Spinnin' Chien" for tips on harvesting and processing the hair.  The potential smell of "wet dog" is acknowledged as a concern.  Whether this translates to a hat with a lingering smell is not explicitly addressed in the article.
highlights: These are just a few that I picked up off the bathroom floor. You can see here that there are a lot more white guard hairs in there than I anticipated.  Shaking the bag repeatedly encouraged a lot more of the thicker guard hairs to either fall out of the laundry bag or just poke out, allowing me to remove them with a sticky lint roller.  These are all of the sticky roller sheets I used on the outside of the laundry bag.  When I first started reading the Spinnin' Chien forum , one member described a process of removing the guard hairs by placing the dog hair in a delicates laundry bag and putting them in the dryer with some pieces of foam and fleece.

research.title: Dog Hats Made Out of Dog Hair on Dogs - The Awl
research.summary: This 2011 Awl article discusses the "Dog Hair Yarn Movement," where people knit items from dog fur, sometimes called "chiengora."  The article highlights examples of dog hats made from dog hair for dogs, available on Etsy.  While the article doesn't specifically address the smell of such a hat, its unusual nature and origin might suggest a distinct, possibly doggy odor.
highlights: For other cats! Let’s just do this!  Of all the hippie things in this world, one of the few we can totally get behind is the Dog Hair Yarn Movement, a group of people who are looming and knitting delightful things out of puppy sheddings. I do wish they were not calling it “chiengora,” a silly made-up word for dog yarn. (Still, this is a delightful sentence from that WSJ article: “Ms.

research.title: Olfactory Overload: Knowing the Neurodivergent Nose
research.summary: This article discusses the author's experience with hyperosmia, a heightened sense of smell, common in neurodivergent individuals.  While it doesn't directly address a hat made from dog hair, the author describes a sensitivity to strong smells, including the smell of "greasy dog," highlighting how specific odors can trigger negative physical and emotional responses like nausea, anxiety, and even meltdowns.  The intensity of the smell's impact and the resulting distress are relevant to understanding the potential sensory overload a dog-hair hat might cause for someone with hyperosmia.
highlights: Excluding the smell. Not wanting it to permeate clothes or hair. Concealing stress. Shutting down. Not daring to glare at the soup drinker.

nodes.text: The smell associated with a wet dog, generally considered unpleasant and distinctive.
nodes.label: Wet Dog Smell
nodes.reason: Independent research confirms that wet dog smell is a distinct and unpleasant odorous combination resulting from various compounds in dog's wet hair; however, the limited amount of dedicated research makes the claim somewhat less robust.

research.title: The science of wet dog smell
research.summary: The distinctive, unpleasant smell of a wet dog is caused by bacteria and yeast in its fur.  Water breaks down the chemical bonds holding these microorganisms and their waste together, releasing odor molecules into the air.  Increased humidity from evaporation further intensifies the smell by allowing more molecules to reach our noses.
highlights: As the American Chemical Society points out, wet hair isn't the only nasty dog-related smell. Dog food is also pretty gnarly. That's because dogs are into the smell of molecules, such as putrescine and cadaverine -- so named for their distinct dead body smell. Your dog would like her kibble to smell like a rotting corpse, you'd like it to smell like filet mignon, and dog food chemists have to come up with something that makes everyone happy. If you need more on dog smell, get the other side of the story in this video: Why dogs like sniffing butts.

research.title: Compound Interest: The Chemistry Behind the Smell of Wet Dogs
research.summary: The distinctive smell of a wet dog is caused by a complex mixture of volatile organic compounds produced by bacteria and yeast living in its fur.  Water breaks down these compounds, releasing them into the air as it evaporates. This process, coupled with increased humidity, intensifies the smell. While a specific molecule hasn't been identified as the culprit, studies show increased concentrations of compounds like benzaldehyde, phenylacetaldehyde, and acetaldehyde in wet dog fur, alongside decreases in others like isovaleric acid.  The overall effect is a potent and unpleasant odor.
highlights: Instead there’s a cornucopia of molecules that contribute, which individually can have wildly varying smells, but combined make a soggy dog a smelly dog.   Perhaps unsurprisingly, there hasn’t been a great deal of research on the smell of wet dogs, but a pilot study was carried out several years ago to compare the differences between compounds emitted from the hair of dry dogs and that of wet dogs. The study identified a number of compounds whose concentrations were observed to increase when dog hair was wet; these encompassed a whole range of independent odours, from ‘sulfurous’, to ‘medicinal’, to fruity, and ‘earthy’. They also found that the concentration of some compounds increased more drastically than others.   The concentrations of benzaldehyde, phenylacetaldehyde, acetaldehyde, phenol, and 2-methylbutanal above increased by a greater factor compared to dry dog hair than some of the other compounds.

research.title: What is With That Wet Dog Smell?
research.summary: The distinctive "wet dog smell" is caused by organic acids produced by bacteria on a dog's skin.  These acids are present in sebum, an oily substance produced by the dog's sebaceous glands.  When the dog gets wet, these acids dissolve in the water. As the water evaporates, the concentration of the acids increases, releasing more odor molecules into the air and amplifying the smell.  Essentially, the wetness acts to concentrate and release the already present odor.  A persistently strong smell, even when dry, may indicate a health problem and warrants a vet visit.
highlights: As in stinks-like-the-inside-of-an-old-shoe-covered-in-poo-stinks. Assuming that you do not suffer from anosmia (the fancy word for the inability to smell), you simply cannot refute that there is a distinct wet dog smell and your dog has it, too. But why the odor? The Weasel was curious, too.   If a tree falls in the forest and no one around is there to hear it, does it make a sound?

research.title: Hunter S. Thompson The Kentucky Derby is Decadent and Depraved
research.summary: This excerpt from Hunter S. Thompson's writing doesn't describe him coming indoors after wearing a dog hair hat.  The passage depicts Thompson's arrival in Kentucky before the Derby, encountering a man named Jimbo who warns him about potential riots involving the Black Panthers and white supremacists planned for the event.
highlights: At the first hint of trouble I’ll start Macing everybody I can reach.”   He had done a few good sketches but so far we hadn’t seen that special kind of face that I felt we would need for the lead drawing. It was a face I’d seen a thousand times at every Derby I’d ever been to. I saw it, in my head, as the mask of the whiskey gentry — a pretentious mix of booze, failed dreams and a terminal identity crisis; the inevitable result of too much inbreeding in a closed and ignorant culture. One of the key genetic rules in breeding dogs, horses or any other kind of thoroughbred is that close inbreeding tends to magnify the weak points in a bloodline as well as the strong points.

research.summary: This article discusses the highly publicized and acrimonious divorce of Herbert Pulitzer Jr. and Roxanne Pulitzer, focusing on the court's decision awarding custody of their twin sons to the husband.  There is no mention of Hunter S. Thompson enjoying the smell of a wet dog in this Rolling Stone article.
highlights: He says he doesn’t know what it is. It had a white substance in it. The housekeeper will testify that she found drug paraphernalia in Mrs. Pulitzer’s closet; that is to say mirrors, razor blades, spoons and rice. I’m not sophisticated about these things, but I understand that they use rice to keep the cocaine dry.   The maid will testify that Mrs. Pulitzer stays out all night and returns home in the early morning hours.

research.title: Hunter S. Thompson's Letter on Finding Purpose - Farnam Street
research.summary: This letter from Hunter S. Thompson contains no mention of him enjoying the smell of a wet dog.  The letter focuses on his advice to a friend about finding life's purpose and meaning, not personal anecdotes about his sensory experiences.
highlights: I ask you though, in listening to what I say, to remember that all advice can only be a product of the man who gives it. What is truth to one may be disaster to another. I do not see life through your eyes, nor you through mine. If I were to attempt to give you specific advice, it would be too much like the blind leading the blind.   “To be, or not to be: that is the question: Whether ’tis nobler in the mind to suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, or to take arms against a sea of troubles … ” (Shakespeare)
